Appendix A Security Analysis

In this section, we provide the definition of our ideal functionalities and proofs for the theorems in Section 5.3 and Section 6.3.

A.1. Proofs for Section 5.3

Theorem 5.1. The protocol of MatMul source layer securely realizes the ideal functionalities ℱMatMulFwsubscriptℱMatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulFw}} and ℱMatMulBwsubscriptℱMatMulBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulBw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

We formally provide the definition and prove the security of the two idea functionalities in Lemma A.1 and A.2, respectively. Putting them together, we complete the proof for Theorem 5.1. ∎

{shadedbox}

Forward propagation of the MatMul source layer ℱMatMulFwsubscriptℱMatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulFw}}

Inputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A inputs features XAsubscript𝑋𝐴X_{A}, secretly shared and/or encrypted models UA,⟦VA⟧BU_{A},\llbracket{V_{A}}\rrbracket_{B}, and keys s​kA,p​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐴𝑝subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{A},pk_{B};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B inputs features XBsubscript𝑋𝐵X_{B}, secretly shared and/or encrypted models UB,⟦VB⟧AU_{B},\llbracket{V_{B}}\rrbracket_{A}, and keys p​kA,s​kB𝑝subscript𝑘𝐴𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵pk_{A},sk_{B}.

Outputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A outputs nothing;

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B outputs Z=XA​WA+XB​WB𝑍subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝑋𝐵subscript𝑊𝐵Z=X_{A}W_{A}+X_{B}W_{B}, where W⋄=U⋄+V⋄subscript𝑊⋄subscript𝑈⋄subscript𝑉⋄W_{\diamond}=U_{\diamond}+V_{\diamond}.

Lemma A.1.

The protocol ΠMatMulFwsubscriptΠMatMulFw\Pi_{\texttt{MatMulFw}} in Line 5-8 of Figure 6 securely realizes ℱMatMulFwsubscriptℱMatMulFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulFw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

First, Party A only receives one message by invoking the ΠHE2SSsubscriptΠHE2SS\Pi_{\texttt{HE2SS}} protocol (Line 6), whilst the other values are computed locally. Therefore, the view of Party A can be perfectly simulated by simulating the ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}} functionality as discussed in Lemma A.5.

Second, Party B receives two messages in the protocol (Line 5 and Line 8). Similarly, the first message can be simulated by simulating the ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}} functionality. Denote the simulated versions of XA​VA−εAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑉𝐴subscript𝜀𝐴X_{A}V_{A}-\varepsilon_{A} and εBsubscript𝜀𝐵\varepsilon_{B} are (XA​VA−εA)∗superscriptsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑉𝐴subscript𝜀𝐴(X_{A}V_{A}-\varepsilon_{A})^{*} and εB∗superscriptsubscript𝜀𝐵\varepsilon_{B}^{*}, respectively. Then, we can simulate the second message, i.e. ZA′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′Z_{A}^{\prime}, by computing ZA′⁣∗=Z−ZB′⁣∗superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′Z_{A}^{\prime*}=Z-Z_{B}^{\prime*}, where ZB′⁣∗=XB​UB+εB∗+(XA​VA−εA)∗superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′subscript𝑋𝐵subscript𝑈𝐵superscriptsubscript𝜀𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑉𝐴subscript𝜀𝐴Z_{B}^{\prime*}=X_{B}U_{B}+\varepsilon_{B}^{*}+(X_{A}V_{A}-\varepsilon_{A})^{*}. As a result, we perfectly simulate the view of Party B. ∎

Lemma A.2.

The protocol ΠMatMulBwsubscriptΠMatMulBw\Pi_{\texttt{MatMulBw}} in Line 9-12 of Figure 6 securely realizes ℱMatMulBwsubscriptℱMatMulBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulBw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

First, Party A receives two messages, which are ⟦∇Z⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B} (Line 9) and ⟦∇WA−ϕ⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{A}-\phi}\rrbracket_{B} (Line 12). Since ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z is the input and ∇WA−ϕ∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\nabla W_{A}-\phi is one piece of random secret, ∇Z∗∇superscript𝑍\nabla Z^{*} (or (∇WA−ϕ)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*}) and ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z (or ∇WA−ϕ∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\nabla W_{A}-\phi) share the same probability distribution. Furthermore, without Party B’s secret key s​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{B}, the ciphertexts ⟦∇Z⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B} (or ⟦∇WA−ϕ⟧delimited-⟦⟧∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\llbracket{\nabla W_{A}-\phi}\rrbracket) and ⟦∇Z∗⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} (or ⟦(∇WA−ϕ)∗⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\llbracket{(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*}}\rrbracket) are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. The other values in the view of Party A are computed locally. For instance, the simulator can simulate ⟦WA⟧B\llbracket{W_{A}}\rrbracket_{B} by computing ⟦WA∗⟧B=XAT⟦∇Z∗⟧B\llbracket{W_{A}^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}=X_{A}^{T}\llbracket{\nabla Z^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}. Again, they are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. Consequently, the view of Party A can be simulated perfectly.

Second, Party B only receives one messages by invoking the ΠHE2SSsubscriptΠHE2SS\Pi_{\texttt{HE2SS}} protocol (Line 10), whilst the other values are computed locally. Therefore, the view of Party B can be perfectly simulated by simulating the ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}} functionality as discussed in Lemma A.5. ∎

Theorem 5.2. Given Z,∇Z𝑍∇𝑍Z,\nabla Z in the MatMul source layer, there are infinite possible values for XA,WA,XA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A},W_{A},X_{A}W_{A}.

Proof.

First, we consider the linear equation Z=ZA+ZB𝑍subscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝑍𝐵Z=Z_{A}+Z_{B} where ZA=XA​WA,ZB=XB​WBformulae-sequencesubscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝑍𝐵subscript𝑋𝐵subscript𝑊𝐵Z_{A}=X_{A}W_{A},Z_{B}=X_{B}W_{B}. With only Z∈ℝB​S×O​U​T𝑍superscriptℝ𝐵𝑆𝑂𝑈𝑇Z\in\mathbb{R}^{BS\times OUT} being known to Party B, there are B​S×O​U​T𝐵𝑆𝑂𝑈𝑇BS\times OUT known values in total. However, since both ZA,ZBsubscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝑍𝐵Z_{A},Z_{B} are unknown, which make up to be 2×B​S×O​U​T2𝐵𝑆𝑂𝑈𝑇2\times BS\times OUT variables in the equation. As a result, there must be infinite possible solution to the equation, which means there are infinite possible values for ZA=XA​WAsubscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴Z_{A}=X_{A}W_{A}. Then, for any possible XA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A}W_{A}, given an arbitrary invertible matrix M∈ℝI​NA×I​NA𝑀superscriptℝ𝐼subscript𝑁𝐴𝐼subscript𝑁𝐴M\in\mathbb{R}^{IN_{A}\times IN_{A}}, we have (XA​M−1)​(M​WA)=XA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴superscript𝑀1𝑀subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴(X_{A}M^{-1})(MW_{A})=X_{A}W_{A}. Consequently, there are infinite possible values for XA,WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A},W_{A}, since both XA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A}W_{A} and M𝑀M are arbitrary.

For ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z, since it is computed locally on Party B, no extra information related to XA,WA,XA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A},W_{A},X_{A}W_{A} are provided. Thus, there are still infinite possible values for XA,WA,XA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A},W_{A},X_{A}W_{A}. ∎

Lemma A.4.

The protocol ΠEmbedMatMulBwsubscriptΠEmbedMatMulBw\Pi_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulBw}} in Line 12-26 of Figure 7 securely realizes ℱEmbedMatMulBwsubscriptℱEmbedMatMulBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulBw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

First, Party A receives six messages, which are ⟦∇Z⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B}, ⟦∇ZVAT⟧B\llbracket{\nabla ZV_{A}^{T}}\rrbracket_{B} (Line 12), ⟦∇WA−ϕ⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{A}-\phi}\rrbracket_{B} (Line 18), ⟦∇WB−ξ⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{B}-\xi}\rrbracket_{B} (Line 19), ∇QB−ρB∇subscript𝑄𝐵subscript𝜌𝐵\nabla Q_{B}-\rho_{B} (Line 23), and ⟦∇QA−ρA⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A}}\rrbracket_{B} (Line 25), respectively. Since ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z is the input and VAsubscript𝑉𝐴V_{A}, ∇WA−ϕ∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\nabla W_{A}-\phi, ∇WB−ξ∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉\nabla W_{B}-\xi, ∇QA−ρA∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A} are random secrets, ∇Z∗∇superscript𝑍\nabla Z^{*} and ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z (or (∇Z​VAT)∗superscript∇𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑉𝐴𝑇(\nabla ZV_{A}^{T})^{*} and ∇Z​VAT∇𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑉𝐴𝑇\nabla ZV_{A}^{T}, or (∇WA−ϕ)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*} and ∇WA−ϕ∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\nabla W_{A}-\phi, or (∇WB−ξ)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉(\nabla W_{B}-\xi)^{*} and ∇WB−ξ∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉\nabla W_{B}-\xi, or (∇QA−ρA)∗superscript∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴(\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A})^{*} and ∇QA−ρA∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A}) share the same probability distribution. Furthermore, without Party B’s secret key s​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{B}, the ciphertexts ⟦∇Z∗⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} and ⟦∇Z⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B} (or ⟦(∇WA−ϕ)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} and ⟦∇WA−ϕ⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{A}-\phi}\rrbracket_{B}, or ⟦(∇WB−ξ)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla W_{B}-\xi)^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} and ⟦∇WB−ξ⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{B}-\xi}\rrbracket_{B}, or ⟦(∇QA−ρA)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A})^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} and ⟦∇QA−ρA⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A}}\rrbracket_{B}) are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. The other values in the view of Party A are computed locally. For instance, the simulator can simulate ⟦∇EA⟧B\llbracket{\nabla E_{A}}\rrbracket_{B} by computing ⟦∇EA∗⟧B=⟦∇Z∗⟧BUAT+⟦(∇ZVAT)∗⟧B\llbracket{\nabla E_{A}^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}=\llbracket{\nabla Z^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}U_{A}^{T}+\llbracket{(\nabla ZV_{A}^{T})^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}. Again, they are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. Consequently, the view of Party A can be simulated perfectly.

For Party B, there are three messages received by invoking the ΠHE2SSsubscriptΠHE2SS\Pi_{\texttt{HE2SS}} protocol (Line 13, 15, and 22), and three messages that are ciphertexts of secrets (Line 17, 20, 26). For the first three messages, we can simulate them by simulating the ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}} functionality. For the last three messages, we simulate them in a similar way as simulating those of Party A, i.e., by randomly picking ciphertexts and encrypting them using p​kA𝑝subscript𝑘𝐴pk_{A}. Again, since the messages are ciphertexts of random secrets, the simulation shares the same probability distribution as the original view and they are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party B. As a result, the simulator perfectly simulates the view of Party B. ∎

Theorem 5.2. Given Z,∇Z𝑍∇𝑍Z,\nabla Z in the Embed-MatMul source layer, there are infinite possible values for XA,QA,WA,EA,EA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A},Q_{A},W_{A},E_{A},E_{A}W_{A}.

Proof.

First, we consider the linear equation Z=ZA+ZB𝑍subscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝑍𝐵Z=Z_{A}+Z_{B} where ZA=EA​WA,ZB=EB​WBformulae-sequencesubscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝑍𝐵subscript𝐸𝐵subscript𝑊𝐵Z_{A}=E_{A}W_{A},Z_{B}=E_{B}W_{B}. With only Z∈ℝB​S×O​U​T𝑍superscriptℝ𝐵𝑆𝑂𝑈𝑇Z\in\mathbb{R}^{BS\times OUT} being known to Party B, there are B​S×O​U​T𝐵𝑆𝑂𝑈𝑇BS\times OUT known values in total. However, since both ZA,ZBsubscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝑍𝐵Z_{A},Z_{B} are unknown, which make up to be 2×B​S×O​U​T2𝐵𝑆𝑂𝑈𝑇2\times BS\times OUT variables in the equation. As a result, there must be infinite possible solution to the equation, which means there are infinite possible values for ZA=XA​EAsubscript𝑍𝐴subscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴Z_{A}=X_{A}E_{A}. Then, for any possible XA​EAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴X_{A}E_{A}, given an arbitrary invertible matrix M∈ℝI​NA×I​NA𝑀superscriptℝ𝐼subscript𝑁𝐴𝐼subscript𝑁𝐴M\in\mathbb{R}^{IN_{A}\times IN_{A}}, we have (EA​M−1)​(M​WA)=EA​WAsubscript𝐸𝐴superscript𝑀1𝑀subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴(E_{A}M^{-1})(MW_{A})=E_{A}W_{A}. Consequently, there are infinite possible values for EA,WAsubscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴E_{A},W_{A}, since both EA​WAsubscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴E_{A}W_{A} and M𝑀M are arbitrary. Similarly, for any possible EAsubscript𝐸𝐴E_{A}, there are also infinite possible values for XA,QAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑄𝐴X_{A},Q_{A}.

For ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z, since it is computed locally on Party B, no extra information related to XA,QA,WA,EA,EA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A},Q_{A},W_{A},E_{A},E_{A}W_{A} are provided. Thus, there are still infinite possible values for XA,QA,WA,EA,EA​WAsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴X_{A},Q_{A},W_{A},E_{A},E_{A}W_{A}. ∎

A.3. Proofs for Common Sub-Routines

Algorithm 1 and Algorthm 2 are two commonly used sub-routines in our work. In this subsection, we prove that the algorithm protocols securely realize the ideal functionalities as defined below.

{shadedbox}

Transformation from HE variables to SS variables ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}}

Inputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄⋄\diamond inputs a ciphertext ⟦v⟧⋄¯\llbracket{v}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}} and the other party’s public key p​k⋄¯𝑝subscript𝑘¯⋄pk_{{\bar{\diamond}}};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}} inputs the secret key s​k⋄¯𝑠subscript𝑘¯⋄sk_{{\bar{\diamond}}}.

Outputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄⋄\diamond outputs a random value ϕitalic-ϕ\phi;

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}} outputs v−ϕ𝑣italic-ϕv-\phi.

Lemma A.5.

The protocol ΠHE2SSsubscriptΠHE2SS\Pi_{\texttt{HE2SS}} in Algorithm 1 securely realizes ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

Since Party ⋄⋄\diamond receives no messages from Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}}, it is easy to know that our protocol is secure against the corruption of Party ⋄⋄\diamond. Hence, we only need to discuss how to simulate the view of Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}}. To do so, the simulator encrypts v−ϕ𝑣italic-ϕv-\phi with p​kB𝑝subscript𝑘𝐵pk_{B} to obtain ⟦v−ϕ⟧⋄¯∗\llbracket{v-\phi}\rrbracket^{*}_{\bar{\diamond}}. Here we differentiate ⟦v−ϕ⟧∗⋄¯\llbracket{v-\phi}\rrbracket^{*}{\bar{\diamond}} and the ⟦v−ϕ⟧⋄¯\llbracket{v-\phi}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}} in Algorithm 1 since they are from different times of encryption. Obviously, they share the same probability distribution and are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}}. As a result, it perfectly simulates the view of Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}}. ∎

{shadedbox}

Transformation from SS variables to HE variables ℱSS2HEsubscriptℱSS2HE\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{SS2HE}}

Inputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄⋄\diamond inputs a piece of SS v⋄subscript𝑣⋄v_{\diamond} and keys p​k⋄,p​k⋄¯𝑝subscript𝑘⋄𝑝subscript𝑘¯⋄pk_{\diamond},pk_{{\bar{\diamond}}};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}} inputs a piece of SS v⋄¯subscript𝑣¯⋄v_{\bar{\diamond}} and keys p​k⋄¯,p​k⋄𝑝subscript𝑘¯⋄𝑝subscript𝑘⋄pk_{{\bar{\diamond}}},pk_{\diamond}.

Outputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄⋄\diamond outputs a ciphertext ⟦v⟧⋄¯\llbracket{v}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party ⋄¯¯⋄{\bar{\diamond}} outputs a ciphertext ⟦v⟧⋄\llbracket{v}\rrbracket_{\diamond}, where v=v⋄+v⋄¯𝑣subscript𝑣⋄subscript𝑣¯⋄v=v_{\diamond}+v_{\bar{\diamond}}.

Lemma A.6.

The protocol ΠSS2HEsubscriptΠSS2HE\Pi_{\texttt{SS2HE}} in Algorithm 2 securely realizes ℱSS2HEsubscriptℱSS2HE\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{SS2HE}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

Since both parties have symmetric routines, we only describe how to simulate the view of Party ⋄⋄\diamond. The only messages received in the protocol is ⟦v⋄¯⟧⋄¯\llbracket{v_{\bar{\diamond}}}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}}. To simulate it, the simulator computes ⟦v⋄¯⟧⋄¯∗=⟦v⟧⋄¯−v⋄\llbracket{v_{\bar{\diamond}}}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}}^{*}=\llbracket{v}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}}-v_{\diamond}. Here we differentiate ⟦v⋄¯⟧⋄¯∗\llbracket{v_{\bar{\diamond}}}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}}^{*} and the ⟦v⋄¯⟧⋄¯\llbracket{v_{\bar{\diamond}}}\rrbracket_{\bar{\diamond}} in Algorithm 2 since they are from different times of encryption. Obviously, they have the same probability distribution since v=v⋄+v⋄¯𝑣subscript𝑣⋄subscript𝑣¯⋄v=v_{\diamond}+v_{\bar{\diamond}}, and they are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party ⋄⋄\diamond. As a result, the view of Party ⋄⋄\diamond can be perfectly simulated. ∎

Appendix B Extension to Federated Top Models

Although the top models are usually non-federated to address efficiency in practice, we can also use a federated top model so that Party B cannot get access to Z𝑍Z or ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z, strengthening the security guarantees. In this section, we discuss how to adapt our work to the federated top model. Without loss of generality, we assume the top model utilizes the SS technique (e.g., SecureML).

First, for the forward propagation, our source layers should output an SS variable ⟨ZA′,ZB′⟩superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′\langle{Z_{A}^{\prime},Z_{B}^{\prime}}\rangle satisfying ZA′+ZB′=Zsuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′𝑍Z_{A}^{\prime}+Z_{B}^{\prime}=Z. In fact, this can be easily done with our algorithm protocols, as described below.

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    For the MatMul source layer, we have the fact that Z⋄′=X⋄​U⋄+ε⋄+X⋄¯​V⋄¯−ε⋄¯superscriptsubscript𝑍⋄′subscript𝑋⋄subscript𝑈⋄subscript𝜀⋄subscript𝑋¯⋄subscript𝑉¯⋄subscript𝜀¯⋄Z_{\diamond}^{\prime}=X_{\diamond}U_{\diamond}+\varepsilon_{\diamond}+X_{\bar{\diamond}}V_{\bar{\diamond}}-\varepsilon_{\bar{\diamond}}, where ε⋄,ε⋄¯subscript𝜀⋄subscript𝜀¯⋄\varepsilon_{\diamond},\varepsilon_{\bar{\diamond}} are generated by different parties. Hence, ⟨ZA′,ZB′⟩superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′\langle{Z_{A}^{\prime},Z_{B}^{\prime}}\rangle forms an SS variable of Z𝑍Z logically. As shown in Line 1 of Figure 13, Party A and Party B return ZA′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′Z_{A}^{\prime} and ZB′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′Z_{B}^{\prime}, respectively. By doing so, we can easily adapt the MatMul source layer to the federated top model.

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Similarly, for the Embed-MatMul source layer, we can also obtain the SS variable ⟨ZA′,ZB′⟩superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′\langle{Z_{A}^{\prime},Z_{B}^{\prime}}\rangle satisfying Z=ZA′,ZB′𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′Z=Z_{A}^{\prime},Z_{B}^{\prime} via Line 5-10 of Figure 7. Thus, we directly output them to the federated top model.

Second, for the backward propagation, Party B no longer gets access to ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z. Instead, both parties take as input an SS variable ⟨ε,∇Z−ε⟩𝜀∇𝑍𝜀\langle{\varepsilon,\nabla Z-\varepsilon}\rangle. For the MatMul source layer, the major difference is that Party B cannot compute model gradients ∇WB=XBT​∇Z∇subscript𝑊𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑋𝐵𝑇∇𝑍\nabla W_{B}=X_{B}^{T}\nabla Z alone. To tackle this problem, we turn the SS variable into an HE variable ⟦∇Z⟧A\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{A} for Party B via Algorithm 2 (Line 3 of Figure 13). Next, Party B proceeds to compute the encrypted model gradients ⟦∇WB⟧A=XBT⟦∇Z⟧A\llbracket{\nabla W_{B}}\rrbracket_{A}=X_{B}^{T}\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{A}, which are then transformed into an SS variable ⟨∇WB−ϕB,ϕB⟩∇subscript𝑊𝐵subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐵subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐵\langle{\nabla W_{B}-\phi_{B},\phi_{B}}\rangle (Line 4-5 of Figure 13). Eventually, the update will be performed based on the secretly shared mode gradients. For the Embed-MatMul source layer, the routines are more complex. We refer interested readers to Figure 14 for more details.

To summarized, the federated source layers proposed in this work can also be integrated with federated top models.

B.1. Security Analysis

In this subsection, we provide the security analysis of BlindFL when the top model is also a federated module. Without loss of generality, we assume the model weights of the federated top model are also secretly shared and/or encrypted. Furthermore, since our work focuses on the security guarantees of federated source layers, we assume the federated top model securely realizes the following ideal functionality for simplicity.

{shadedbox}

Forward and backward propagation of SS-based top model ℱTopSSsubscriptℱTopSS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{TopSS}}

Inputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A inputs secretly shared activations ZA′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′Z_{A}^{\prime}, secretly shared and/or encrypted models of the top model, and keys s​kA,p​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐴𝑝subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{A},pk_{B};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B inputs inputs secretly shared activations ZB′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′Z_{B}^{\prime}, labels y𝑦y, secretly shared and/or encrypted models of the top model, and keys p​kA,s​kB𝑝subscript𝑘𝐴𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵pk_{A},sk_{B}.

Outputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A outputs ε𝜀\varepsilon;

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B outputs ∇Z−ε∇𝑍𝜀\nabla Z-\varepsilon, where ∇Z∇𝑍\nabla Z denotes the backward derivatives of Z=ZA′+ZB′𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′Z=Z_{A}^{\prime}+Z_{B}^{\prime}.

Then, we identify the ideal functionality of ML training of BlindFL with an SS-based top model, and provide the security guarantees in Theorem B.1.

{shadedbox}

ML Training of BlindFL with an SS-based top model ℱMLsubscriptℱML\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{ML}}

Inputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A inputs features XAsubscript𝑋𝐴X_{A} and keys s​kA,p​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐴𝑝subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{A},pk_{B};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B inputs features XBsubscript𝑋𝐵X_{B}, labels y𝑦y, and keys p​kA,s​kB𝑝subscript𝑘𝐴𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵pk_{A},sk_{B}.

Outputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Both parties output the trained federated source layers and Party B further outputs the trained federated top model (model weights are secretly shared or encrypted).

Theorem B.1.

Assume the federated top model ΠTopSSsubscriptΠTopSS\Pi_{\texttt{TopSS}} securely realizes ℱTopSSsubscriptℱTopSS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{TopSS}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party. The training of BlindFL using the MatMul and Embed-MatMul federated source layers securely realizes ℱMLsubscriptℱML\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{ML}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

Since all values are secretly shared and/or encrypted during the training process, it is actually a hybrid interaction of the ΠMatMulSSFwsubscriptΠMatMulSSFw\Pi_{\texttt{MatMulSSFw}}, ΠMatMulSSBwsubscriptΠMatMulSSBw\Pi_{\texttt{MatMulSSBw}}, ΠEmbed-MatMulSSFwsubscriptΠEmbed-MatMulSSFw\Pi_{\texttt{Embed-MatMulSSFw}}, ΠEmbed-MatMulSSBwsubscriptΠEmbed-MatMulSSBw\Pi_{\texttt{Embed-MatMulSSBw}}, and ΠTopSSsubscriptΠTopSS\Pi_{\texttt{TopSS}} protocols. Therefore, simulation can be done using the hybrid argument. Combing Lemma B.2,  B.3,  B.4,  B.5, and the assumption on the federated top model, we prove Theorem B.1. ∎

Lemma B.2.

The protocol ΠMatMulSSFwsubscriptΠMatMulSSFw\Pi_{\texttt{MatMulSSFw}} in Line 1 of Figure 13 securely realizes ℱMatMulSSFwsubscriptℱMatMulSSFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulSSFw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Backward propagation of the MatMul source layer

followed by an SS-based top model ℱMatMulSSBwsubscriptℱMatMulSSBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulSSBw}}

  • ▷▷\triangleright

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B outputs ∇WA−ϕA,ϕB∇subscript𝑊𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐵\nabla W_{A}-\phi_{A},\phi_{B}, where ∇W⋄=X⋄T​∇Z∇subscript𝑊⋄superscriptsubscript𝑋⋄𝑇∇𝑍\nabla W_{\diamond}=X_{\diamond}^{T}\nabla Z.

Lemma B.3.

The protocol ΠMatMulSSBwsubscriptΠMatMulSSBw\Pi_{\texttt{MatMulSSBw}} in Line 2-8 of Figure 13 securely realizes ℱMatMulSSBwsubscriptℱMatMulSSBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{MatMulSSBw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

Since both parties have symmetric routines, we only describe how to simulate the view of Party A. There are three messages received in the protocol. For the first two messages, i.e., ⟦∇Z⟧B,∇WB−ϕB\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B},\nabla W_{B}-\phi_{B} (Line 3 and 5), they can be simulated by simulating the ΠSS2HEsubscriptΠSS2HE\Pi_{\texttt{SS2HE}} and ΠHE2SSsubscriptΠHE2SS\Pi_{\texttt{HE2SS}} protocols, respectively. For the third message, i.e., ⟦∇WA−ϕA⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{A}-\phi_{A}}\rrbracket_{B} (Line 7), we construct a simulator that randomly picks plaintexts (∇WA−ϕA)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴(\nabla W_{A}-\phi_{A})^{*} and encrypts them using p​kB𝑝subscript𝑘𝐵pk_{B} to obtain ⟦(∇WA−ϕA)∗⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴\llbracket{(\nabla W_{A}-\phi_{A})^{*}}\rrbracket. Since ∇WA−ϕA∇subscript𝑊𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴\nabla W_{A}-\phi_{A} is one piece of random secret, (∇WA−ϕA)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴(\nabla W_{A}-\phi_{A})^{*} and ∇WA−ϕA∇subscript𝑊𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴\nabla W_{A}-\phi_{A} share the same probability distribution. Furthermore, without Party B’s secret key s​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{B}, ⟦∇WA−ϕ⟧delimited-⟦⟧∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\llbracket{\nabla W_{A}-\phi}\rrbracket and ⟦(∇WA−ϕ)∗⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\llbracket{(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*}}\rrbracket are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. The other values in the view of Party A are computed locally. For instance, denoting ⟦∇Z∗⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} as the simulated version of ⟦∇Z⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B}, the simulator can simulate ⟦WA⟧B\llbracket{W_{A}}\rrbracket_{B} by computing ⟦WA∗⟧B=XAT⟦∇Z∗⟧B\llbracket{W_{A}^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}=X_{A}^{T}\llbracket{\nabla Z^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}. Again, they are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. Consequently, the view of Party A can be simulated perfectly. ∎

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B inputs features XBsubscript𝑋𝐵X_{B}, secretly shared and/or encrypted models SB,⟦TB⟧A,TA,UB,⟦VB⟧A,⟦UA⟧A,VAS_{B},\llbracket{T_{B}}\rrbracket_{A},T_{A},U_{B},\llbracket{V_{B}}\rrbracket_{A},\llbracket{U_{A}}\rrbracket_{A},V_{A}, and keys p​kA,s​kB𝑝subscript𝑘𝐴𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵pk_{A},sk_{B}.

Outputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A outputs ZA′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′Z_{A}^{\prime};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party B outputs ZB′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′Z_{B}^{\prime}, where ZA′+ZB′=EA​WA+EB​WB,E⋄=lkup​(Q⋄,X⋄),Q⋄=S⋄+T⋄,W⋄=U⋄+V⋄formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝐴′superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐵′subscript𝐸𝐴subscript𝑊𝐴subscript𝐸𝐵subscript𝑊𝐵formulae-sequencesubscript𝐸⋄lkupsubscript𝑄⋄subscript𝑋⋄formulae-sequencesubscript𝑄⋄subscript𝑆⋄subscript𝑇⋄subscript𝑊⋄subscript𝑈⋄subscript𝑉⋄Z_{A}^{\prime}+Z_{B}^{\prime}=E_{A}W_{A}+E_{B}W_{B},E_{\diamond}=\textup{lkup}(Q_{\diamond},X_{\diamond}),Q_{\diamond}=S_{\diamond}+T_{\diamond},W_{\diamond}=U_{\diamond}+V_{\diamond}.

Lemma B.4.

The protocol ΠEmbedMatMulSSFwsubscriptΠEmbedMatMulSSFw\Pi_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulSSFw}} in Line 1 of Figure 14 securely realizes ℱEmbedMatMulSSFwsubscriptℱEmbedMatMulSSFw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulSSFw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

This lemma can be proved similarly as Lemma A.3. Thus, we would like to refer readers to the proof of Lemma A.3. ∎

Backward propagation of the Embed-MatMul source layer

followed by an SS-based top model ℱEmbedMatMulSSBwsubscriptℱEmbedMatMulSSBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulSSBw}}

Inputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A inputs features XAsubscript𝑋𝐴X_{A}, secretly shared derivatives ε𝜀\varepsilon, secretly shared activations ψA,EB−ψBsubscript𝜓𝐴subscript𝐸𝐵subscript𝜓𝐵\psi_{A},E_{B}-\psi_{B}, secretly shared and/or encrypted models SA,⟦TA⟧B,TB,UA,⟦VA⟧B,⟦UB⟧B,VBS_{A},\llbracket{T_{A}}\rrbracket_{B},T_{B},U_{A},\llbracket{V_{A}}\rrbracket_{B},\llbracket{U_{B}}\rrbracket_{B},V_{B}, and keys s​kA,p​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐴𝑝subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{A},pk_{B};

  • ▷▷\triangleright

Outputs:

  • ▷▷\triangleright

    Party A outputs ϕ,ξ,ρA,∇QA−ρBitalic-ϕ𝜉subscript𝜌𝐴∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐵\phi,\xi,\rho_{A},\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{B};

    Party B outputs ∇WA−ϕ,∇WB−ξ,∇QA−ρA,ρB∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴subscript𝜌𝐵\nabla W_{A}-\phi,\nabla W_{B}-\xi,\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A},\rho_{B}, where ∇W⋄=E⋄T​∇Z,∇E⋄=∇Z​W⋄T,∇Q⋄=lkup_bw​(∇E⋄,X⋄)formulae-sequence∇subscript𝑊⋄superscriptsubscript𝐸⋄𝑇∇𝑍formulae-sequence∇subscript𝐸⋄∇𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑊⋄𝑇∇subscript𝑄⋄lkup_bw∇subscript𝐸⋄subscript𝑋⋄\nabla W_{\diamond}=E_{\diamond}^{T}\nabla Z,\nabla E_{\diamond}=\nabla ZW_{\diamond}^{T},\nabla Q_{\diamond}=\textup{lkup\_bw}(\nabla E_{\diamond},X_{\diamond}).

Lemma B.5.

The protocol ΠEmbedMatMulSSBwsubscriptΠEmbedMatMulSSBw\Pi_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulSSBw}} in Line 2-10 of Figure 7 securely realizes ℱEmbedMatMulSSBwsubscriptℱEmbedMatMulSSBw\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulSSBw}} in the presence of a semi-honest adversary that can corrupt one party.

Proof.

Since both parties have symmetric routines, we only describe how to simulate the view of Party A. There are eight messages received in total.

First, for the four messages received in Line 3, 5, 6, and 8 of Figure 14, they are received by invoking the ΠHE2SSsubscriptΠHE2SS\Pi_{\texttt{HE2SS}} and ΠSS2HEsubscriptΠSS2HE\Pi_{\texttt{SS2HE}} protocols, so we can simulate them by simulating the ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}} and ℱSS2HEsubscriptℱSS2HE\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{SS2HE}} functionalities.

The ΠEmbedMatMulSSBwsubscriptΠEmbedMatMulSSBw\Pi_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulSSBw}} protocol in Figure 14 also involves parts of the ΠEmbedMatMulBwsubscriptΠEmbedMatMulBw\Pi_{\texttt{EmbedMatMulBw}} protocol in Figure 7, where four messages are also received (Line 18, 19, 23, and 25 of Figure 7). For the message received in Line 23 of Figure 7, we can simulate it by simulating the ℱHE2SSsubscriptℱHE2SS\mathcal{F}_{\texttt{HE2SS}} functionalities. For the other three messages received in Line 18, 19, and 25 of Figure 7, we construct a simulator that randomly picks plaintexts (∇WA−ϕ)∗,(∇WB−ξ)∗,(∇QA−ρA)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕsuperscript∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉superscript∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*},(\nabla W_{B}-\xi)^{*},(\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A})^{*} and encrypts them using p​kB𝑝subscript𝑘𝐵pk_{B} to obtain ⟦(∇WA−ϕ)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}, ⟦(∇WB−ξ)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla W_{B}-\xi)^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}, ⟦(∇QA−ρA)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A})^{*}}\rrbracket_{B}. Since ∇WA−ϕ,∇WB−ξ,∇QA−ρA∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴\nabla W_{A}-\phi,\nabla W_{B}-\xi,\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A} are random secrets, (∇WA−ϕ)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*} and ∇WA−ϕ∇subscript𝑊𝐴italic-ϕ\nabla W_{A}-\phi (or (∇WB−ξ)∗superscript∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉(\nabla W_{B}-\xi)^{*} and ∇WB−ξ∇subscript𝑊𝐵𝜉\nabla W_{B}-\xi, or (∇QA−ρA)∗superscript∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴(\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A})^{*} and ∇QA−ρA∇subscript𝑄𝐴subscript𝜌𝐴\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A}) share the same probability distribution. Furthermore, without Party B’s secret key s​kB𝑠subscript𝑘𝐵sk_{B}, the ciphertexts ⟦(∇WA−ϕ)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla W_{A}-\phi)^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} and ⟦∇WA−ϕ⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{A}-\phi}\rrbracket_{B} (or ⟦(∇WB−ξ)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla W_{B}-\xi)^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} and ⟦∇WB−ξ⟧B\llbracket{\nabla W_{B}-\xi}\rrbracket_{B}, or ⟦(∇QA−ρA)∗⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A})^{*}}\rrbracket_{B} and ⟦∇QA−ρA⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Q_{A}-\rho_{A}}\rrbracket_{B}) are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. Therefore, they can be perfectly simulated.

The other values in the view of Party A are computed locally. For instance, denoting the simulated version of ⟦∇Z⟧B\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B}, ⟦(∇Z−ε)VAT⟧B\llbracket{(\nabla Z-\varepsilon)V_{A}^{T}}\rrbracket_{B} as ⟦∇Z⟧B∗\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B}^{*}, ⟦(∇Z−ε)VAT⟧B∗\llbracket{(\nabla Z-\varepsilon)V_{A}^{T}}\rrbracket_{B}^{*}, respectively, the simulator can simulate ⟦EA⟧B\llbracket{E_{A}}\rrbracket_{B} by computing ⟦EA⟧B∗=⟦∇Z⟧B∗UAT+⟦(∇Z−ε)VAT⟧B∗+ε⟦VAT⟧B\llbracket{E_{A}}\rrbracket_{B}^{*}=\llbracket{\nabla Z}\rrbracket_{B}^{*}U_{A}^{T}+\llbracket{(\nabla Z-\varepsilon)V_{A}^{T}}\rrbracket_{B}^{*}+\varepsilon\llbracket{V_{A}^{T}}\rrbracket_{B}. Again, they are computationally indistinguishable from the perspective of Party A. Consequently, the view of Party A can be simulated perfectly. ∎

Appendix C Extension to Multi-Party Learning

Although we focus on the two-party setting throughout this paper, the proposed federated source layers of BlindFL can also be generalized to the multi-party setting where there are two or more Party A’s. Here we provide an example of how to adapt the MatMul source layer to more than one Party A’s. The adaption for Embed-MatMul can be achieved similarly.

The multi-party MatMul source layer is presented in Algorithm 3. The idea is to secretly share the model weights of each Party A with Party B one by one and let all Party A’s execute the same routines. To be specific, for the i𝑖i-th Party A (denoted as Party A(i)), the model weights are secretly shared as WA​(i)=UA​(i)+VA​(i)subscript𝑊𝐴𝑖subscript𝑈𝐴𝑖subscript𝑉𝐴𝑖W_{A(i)}=U_{A(i)}+V_{A(i)}, where VA​(i)subscript𝑉𝐴𝑖V_{A(i)} is managed by Party B. For Party B, the model weights are broken into more pieces, i.e., WB=UB+∑iVB​(i)subscript𝑊𝐵subscript𝑈𝐵subscript𝑖subscript𝑉𝐵𝑖W_{B}=U_{B}+\sum_{i}V_{B(i)}, where VB​(i)subscript𝑉𝐵𝑖V_{B(i)} is managed by Party A(i).

Consequently, the goal of forward propagation is to compute the following results:

Z𝑍\displaystyle Z =∑iXA​(i)​WA​(i)+XB​WBabsentsubscript𝑖subscript𝑋𝐴𝑖subscript𝑊𝐴𝑖subscript𝑋𝐵subscript𝑊𝐵\displaystyle=\sum_{i}X_{A(i)}W_{A(i)}+X_{B}W_{B}
=∑iXA​(i)​(UA​(i)+VA​(i))+XB​(UB+∑iVB​(i))absentsubscript𝑖subscript𝑋𝐴𝑖subscript𝑈𝐴𝑖subscript𝑉𝐴𝑖subscript𝑋𝐵subscript𝑈𝐵subscript𝑖subscript𝑉𝐵𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{i}X_{A(i)}(U_{A(i)}+V_{A(i)})+X_{B}(U_{B}+\sum_{i}V_{B(i)})
=∑i(XA​(i)​UA​(i)+XA​(i)​VA​(i)+XB​UBM+XB​VB​(i)),absentsubscript𝑖subscript𝑋𝐴𝑖subscript𝑈𝐴𝑖subscript𝑋𝐴𝑖subscript𝑉𝐴𝑖subscript𝑋𝐵subscript𝑈𝐵𝑀subscript𝑋𝐵subscript𝑉𝐵𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{i}\large(X_{A(i)}U_{A(i)}+X_{A(i)}V_{A(i)}+X_{B}\frac{U_{B}}{M}+X_{B}V_{B(i)}\large),

where M𝑀M is the number of Party A’s. This can be reckoned as performing federated matrix multiplication between Party B and each Party A(i), respectively, and summing up the M𝑀M intermediate results to achieve the final results. The detailed routines are presented in Line 12-19 of Algorithm 3.

For the backward propagation, Party B can still compute model gradients ∇WB=XBT​∇Z∇subscript𝑊𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑋𝐵𝑇∇𝑍\nabla W_{B}=X_{B}^{T}\nabla Z on its own. For Party A(i), it only needs to achieve the secretly shared model gradients ⟨ϕA​(i),∇WA​(i)−ϕA​(i)⟩subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴𝑖∇subscript𝑊𝐴𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐴𝑖\langle{\phi_{A(i)},\nabla W_{A(i)}-\phi_{A(i)}}\rangle via a similar routine as Figure 6. Line 20-31 of Algorithm 3 shows the detailed procedure.

Finally, it is worthy to note that here we only provide a simple method to extend BlindFL to the multi-party setting. It is interesting to explore how to optimize the algorithm protocols with smaller computation complexity and fewer communication rounds. We would like to leave them as our future work.

Appendix D More experiments

D.1. Experiments on Fashion MNIST

In Section 7, we conduct our experiments on tabular datasets. To evaluate whether our work also supports more kinds of datasets, we conduct experiments on the Fashion MNIST (fmnist) dataset in this section. To be specific, we split each image into two 14×\times28 subfigures to simulate the feature partitioning in VFL. Then, we train the MLP models over the partitioned dataset. As shown in Table C and Figure 15, the results are consistent with those on other datasets. First, BlindFL runs faster than SecureML without client aided but slower than the client-aided SecureML. Second, BlindFL has a similar convergence as non-federated learning on collocated data (NonFed-collocated), and achieves better performance than non-federated learning on the features of Party B only (NonFed-Party B), verifying the lossless property of our work.

D.2. Scalability

In this section, we train the MLP models on the connect-4 dataset to empirically evaluate the scalability of our work.

Scalability w.r.t. #hidden dim. We first fix the number of hidden layers as 3 and vary the output dimensionality of the first layer, i.e., the MatMul source layer. (The output dimensionalities of the second and third layers are fixed as 16 and 3, respectively.) As shown in Table C, when the first layer is wider, the validation accuracy increases slightly, whilst the training time cost increases almost proportionally. This is because the number of cryptography operations in the MatMul source layer also increases correspondingly.

Scalability w.r.t. #layers. Then, we assess the effect of the number of layers. To do so, we fix the output dimensionalities of the first and the last but one layers as 64 and 16, and vary the number of layers by inserting 32-unit layers in the middle. For instance, in the 4-layer case, the output dimensionalities of all layers are 64, 32, 16, and 3, respectively. As shown in Table C, the number of layers does not affect the training time cost significantly. This is reasonable since the top model is a non-federated module and the major overhead is the MatMul source layer.
